Hello, my sister, child, and I came from Ukraine, and we are currently in the process of getting our documents and looking for work. Could you please suggest if there are any organizations that help with food, household chemicals, and essential items during the initial period?

First, go to MOM, it is on Pereulok Gorny 3, they provide grocery cards for the supermarket and a pharmacy card. Then, if the child is under three years old, you can contact "Happy Baby," they immediately issue a grocery set and you can also take clothes from the "Open Wardrobe" once every couple of months. You can contact the Red Cross, their principle is that if they have something, they will give it, if not, they will record it and promise to give something. But I don't remember if they need plastic (a certificate of additional protection application). UNICEF definitely provides financial support sometimes, but you need plastic to register with them.
I contacted the Red Cross and UNICEF just for registration, received certificates and 700 rubles of assistance from the Red Cross. I have not yet applied for protection.

Please tell me, which specific medical examination does my husband need to undergo?

Good day. If a medical examination is necessary for the documents for a residence permit, then go to the nearest clinic, tell them what you need the medical examination for, and enter into an agreement with the clinic. In this clinic, you will take blood and urine tests, see some doctors (urologist), and have a fluorography. They will also give you a referral for an HIV blood test (at 4 Klara Tsetkin Street), where you can also take tests for syphilis - this is necessary. Then, with the results of the urologist, HIV, and syphilis tests, go to 46a Prilukskaya Street, where a dermatovenerologist will give a conclusion on the absence of diseases based on the tests. Then return to the clinic where you have an agreement, where the results of the urine and blood tests you took earlier, as well as fluorography (you need to pick up the result yourself), are already available. Based on this, the clinic will issue you a health certificate for OGIM. I‚Äôll add that if you are obtaining a certificate for a residence permit, all tests and consultations are paid, and you will have to pay about 250 rubles in total, whereas for temporary protection it is free, or at least partially free. The medical certificate is valid for a month.

RB will not be able to lift the restrictions for you as they were imposed by RF. Until RF lifts them, the ban will remain in RB.

It is a personalized card and an account to boot. It takes 5 days.

I won't tell you that. But the clinic clarified for which status a medical certificate is required. It's possible that tests will be free with additional protection.
I don't think there are any. HIV, syphilis, and dermatologists are handled in specialized institutions. I indicated the addresses above.

A temporary residence permit is issued under two conditions: additional protection and employment. Choose the way that is most convenient for you to obtain a temporary residence permit.

Residence permit and additional protection are like red and hot. They seem similar but relate to different legal areas. There is no such thing as having separate laws in a particular city; he either continues to apply for a temporary residence permit for work, or applies for additional protection (and this needs to be done quickly). If there is nothing else: own housing, relatives, etc.

text_entities.TRANSLATED_TEXT: Good evening! Please share your reviews if anyone has encountered transporting personal belongings when crossing the border from Europe to Belarus? If you read the rules, each person is allowed to carry up to 25 kg of items. But at the same time, I found information that this does not apply to personal items that have been used and are necessary on the road and at the destination. But the list of these items does not include everything. Therefore, I would like to know from the personal experience of channel members if it is possible to carry with you, for example, a used TV, microwave, and power tools? Thanks in advance to everyone for the answers.

Good evening. All small household appliances (used) will not be considered by weight, they are considered personal belongings. I recommend making a list of such items because at the border they will ask what you are bringing, and it's better to be prepared. Everything will need to be taken out and shown.
Thank you for your answers!
Here is a link about transportation, there are all the answers in the pinned posts
Please send links where you read everything. You can also do it in private. Thank you.

Good evening, I entered in November 2024, all used equipment (vegetable dryer, computer and peripherals, robot vacuum cleaner) except for the laptop went by weight, dishes, computer desk and chair, winter tires for the car I was driving. Absolutely everything is used. Paid 1k euros for customs clearance by weight (4 euros per kg). You can only bring one computer monitor per year. The second one is not possible at all, neither for money nor for free. I encountered two shifts, during the first shift I got a young female inspector completely lacking empathy. She said to weigh absolutely everything that is not attached to the car, including bedding and clothes (all personal used items). By the time I finished unloading and started weighing, the shift changed. In the second shift, the female inspector had a human approach and pointed out what needed to be weighed and what was considered personal items and didn't need to be. If it wasn't for her, I would have paid twice as much. During the process, everything will need to be unloaded completely. Show every bag and box and what's inside. Weigh, record in the declaration (all equipment separately along with serial numbers, dishes, for example, with one entry but approximately describing what's there in brackets) and give an approximate value in euros (since it's used, i.e., how much you estimate it, not how much you bought it new). If everything being imported exceeds a certain amount (I think 10k euros, but I'm not sure), there is also some percentage of that amount that needs to be paid. The price indicated in the declaration can (and most likely will) be checked. Therefore, I advise everyone who is planning to bring a lot to approach this issue carefully. It greatly varies what and how much can be brought if you do not have a residence permit or other documents confirming residence in Belarus and you are not a citizen of Belarus. I saw somewhere, but I might be confused, that for carriers it is considered 2 euros per kg, and for large volumes, it might be more profitable to transport through them.
